title: AB 250
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward," "distant site," "health care provider," and "originating site." Telehealth is the delivery of healthcare services via technology to diagnose, consult, treat, educate, and manage patient care remotely. It includes real-time interactions and asynchronous store and forward transfers. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, the provider must inform the patient, obtain consent, and document it. Patients can still receive in-person care if they agree to telehealth first. Non-compliance is considered unprofessional conduct. This section does not change a provider's scope of practice or allow unauthorized healthcare delivery. The scope of practice for healthcare providers remains unchanged with telehealth. Patient confidentiality laws apply to telehealth interactions. The section does not apply to patients in correctional facilities. The section excludes patients in correctional facilities. Hospitals can grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers based on medical staff recommendations. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure exams must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks, with no more than 40 hours in a week and at least 1,700 hours supervised post-degree. The applicant must complete a minimum of 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks, with no more than 40 hours in a week. Additionally, at least 1,700 hours of supervised experience must be completed after obtaining a qualifying master's or doctoral degree. No more than 1,300 hours of supervised experience can be obtained before completing the degree, and no more than 750 hours of counseling and direct supervisor contact can be credited before degree completion. Experience cannot be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. No hours of experience can be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Experience cannot be gained more than six years prior to filing for examination eligibility, with exceptions for up to 500 hours of clinical experience in supervised practicum. A maximum of 1,000 hours of combined experience in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities is allowed. The applicant can gain up to 1,000 hours of experience in direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities, including workshops, seminars, training sessions, conferences, and personal psychotherapy. Not more than 500 hours of experience in group therapy or counseling, administering psychological tests, client advocacy, diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, and providing personal psychotherapy or counseling via telehealth. (11) Up to 375 hours of experience in personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or counseling services via telehealth. (12) Emphasis on working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. Applies to hours gained after January 1, 2010. The subdivision applies to hours gained after January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised to ensure counseling aligns with their training. Supervised experience can only be gained as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. An intern must provide W-2 tax forms or a verification letter from their employer when applying for licensure. Supervision requires one hour of direct contact with a supervisor each week for credited experience, with specific guidelines for trainees. Trainees must receive one hour of direct supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with a maximum of six hours of supervision per week. Additional supervision is required for individuals with more than 10 hours of client contact per week. Direct supervisor contact can be individual or group-based, and must occur within the same week as the hours claimed. (3) "One hour of direct supervisor contact" is defined as one hour per week of face-to-face contact individually or two hours per week in a group. (4) This contact must occur within the same week as the claimed hours. (5) Group contact should be with a maximum of eight supervisees for at least one continuous hour. (6) Interns in specific settings can use real-time videoconferencing for supervisor contact. (7) The supervisor must monitor all experience gained by the trainee as per regulations. A trainee's supervised experience must be monitored by the supervisor. The six hours of weekly supervision credit applies from January 1, 2009. The trainee can receive credit for supervised experience in a setting that lawfully provides mental health counseling, meets experience and supervision requirements, and is within the scope of practice. An intern's supervised experience must meet oversight requirements and be within the scope of practice. The setting must lawfully provide mental health counseling or psychotherapy for the experience to be credited. An intern can receive credit for supervised experience in a setting that provides mental health counseling or psychotherapy and ensures oversight. The intern must not work in a private practice until registered. Employers are encouraged to provide fair remuneration to interns. An intern in a private practice must be supervised by a licensee and gain experience solely related to their position. To gain experience towards licensure, interns must register with the board and apply within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. They should not receive payment from patients or clients, only from their employers. Trainees, interns, and applicants must work at their employer's business location under supervision. Interns and trainees under licensed supervision can provide telehealth services within authorized scope. They should not have any financial interest in their employer's business. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses in lawful work settings are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to prove expenses were incurred. Each educational institution preparing applicants for licensure should consider requiring and encouraging counseling or psychotherapy for students. Supervisors should also advise interns and trainees on the benefits of counseling. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
